statement: Although the problem model is introduced in the research plan, it is challenging to connect it with specific examples of resource allocation beyond the brief mentions of LLM services and edge intelligence systems.
The research plan mentions a use case for the MSB-PRS framework in the LLM context, but it is unclear if this could be practical or feasibly deployed in that context.
The utility function definition in the method section, where reward is scaled by the priority parameter, lacks a practical example to clarify this definition.

The learning component of the proposed algorithm and the regret analysis approach are fairly standard, as there exists an optimal matching between plays and arms, and the remaining task is to target this optimal matching through UCB strategy, as done in much of the literature.

The real challenge posed by stochastic capacity in the proposed model is unclear, as it is difficult to assess whether the stochastic realization actually makes the problem more challenging due to randomness or possibly easier given known observations.

The bipartite graph formulation approach depends on locating the maximum weight matching, but the research plan lacks theoretical guarantee supporting the claim that this approach is theoretically optimal.

The planned experiments are overly simplistic and do not thoroughly describe how the baseline algorithms OnlinActPrf and OnlinActPrf-v will be adapted to make a fair comparison with the novel MSB-PRS approach.
